case_name: Sawatram Ramprasad Mills Co., Ltd., Akola v. Workmen

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 525 of 1964 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 525 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 25, 1962 of the Bombay High Court  Nagpur

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated August 25, 1962 of Bombay High Court Nagpur Bench in Special Civil Application No. 360 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated August 25, 1962 of the Bombay High Court  Nagpur Bench  at Nagpur in Special Civil Application No. 360 of 1961. 76 5 S. Bobde G. L. Sanghi and Sardar Bahadur, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant is Sawatram Ramprasad Mills Co., Ltd., Akola.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by certificate against the judgment of the Bombay High Court dated August 25, 1962 the appellant is the Sawatram Ramprasad Mills Co., Ltd., Akola and the respondents two of the workmen of the Mills.

facts.text: Respondents are two workmen of the Mills.

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal by certificate against the judgment of the Bombay High Court dated August 25, 1962 the appellant is the Sawatram Ramprasad Mills Co., Ltd., Akola and the respondents two of the workmen of the Mills. The respondents are claiming from the Mills companypensation for lay off from March 5, 1960 to October 22, 1960.

facts.text: Respondents claiming compensation for lay off from March 5, 1960 to October 22, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents two of the workmen of the Mills. The respondents are claiming from the Mills companypensation for lay off from March 5, 1960 to October 22, 1960. The proceedings were companymenced by an application to the Second Labour Court, Bombay under s. 33C 1  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  Act XIV of 1947 .

facts.text: Application filed to Second Labour Court, Bombay under s. 33C(1) of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The proceedings were companymenced by an application to the Second Labour Court, Bombay under s. 33C 1  of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947  Act XIV of 1947 . The Mills objected on various grounds including firstly that the Second Labour Court had numberjurisdiction to hear the case as the dispute fell to be tried under the C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act, 1947

facts.text: Mills objected that Second Labour Court had no jurisdiction as dispute under C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Mills objected on various grounds including firstly that the Second Labour Court had numberjurisdiction to hear the case as the dispute fell to be tried under the C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act, 1947 and, secondly, that the application under s. 33C, in any event, was incompetent.

facts.text: Mills objected that application under s. 33C was incompetent.

anchor.surface_text: the dispute fell to be tried under the C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act, 1947 and, secondly, that the application under s. 33C, in any event, was incompetent. The Second Labour Court held against the Mills on both the grounds.

facts.text: Second Labour Court held against Mills on both grounds.

anchor.surface_text: that the application under s. 33C, in any event, was incompetent. The Second Labour Court held against the Mills on both the grounds. The Mills applied to the High Court of Bombay under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution but by the judgment under appeal their application was dismissed.

facts.text: Mills applied to Bombay High Court under Arts. 226 and 227, application dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The Second Labour Court held against the Mills on both the grounds. The Mills applied to the High Court of Bombay under Arts. 226 and 227 of the Constitution but by the judgment under appeal their application was dismissed. It may be pointed out here that there were similar applications for company- pensation for lay off by the other workmen of the Mills

facts.text: Similar applications for compensation for lay off by other workmen, heard together on preliminary point.

anchor.surface_text: their application was dismissed. It may be pointed out here that there were similar applications for company- pensation for lay off by the other workmen of the Mills and on this preliminary point they were all heard together. In this Court only these two grounds were urged.

facts.text: In Supreme Court, only two grounds urged.

anchor.surface_text: the Mills and on this preliminary point they were all heard together. In this Court only these two grounds were urged. The company- tention on behalf of the Mills on the first ground was two- fold.

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Act passed in 1947, brought into force on April 1, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The Industrial Disputes Act was passed in 1947 and was brought into force on April 1, 1947. It is number disputed that it applied to the Textile Industry. The C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act  23 of 1947  came into force on June 2, 1947

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Act applied to Textile Industry, not disputed.

anchor.surface_text: brought into force on April 1, 1947. It is number disputed that it applied to the Textile Industry. The C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act  23 of 1947  came into force on June 2, 1947 but only the first section was then brought into force.

facts.text: C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes Settlement Act 23 of 1947 came into force on June 2, 1947 for first section.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed that it applied to the Textile Industry. The C.P. Berar Industrial Disputes  Settlement  Act  23 of 1947  came into force on June 2, 1947 but only the first section was then brought into force. Later, the remaining sections were brought into force by a numberification dated November 20, 1947

facts.text: Remaining sections of C.P. Berar Act brought into force November 20, 1947 in all industries except Textile.

anchor.surface_text: Settlement  Act  23 of 1947  came into force on June 2, 1947 but only the first section was then brought into force. Later, the remaining sections were brought into force by a numberification dated November 20, 1947 in all industries except the Textile Industry.

facts.text: C.P. Berar Act made applicable to Textile industry from March 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: dated November 20, 1947 in all industries except the Textile Industry. From March 1, 1951, the Act was also, 76 6 made applicable to the Textile industry. In 1953 the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 was amended by Industrial Disputes  Amendment  Act, 1953.

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Act amended in 1953 by Industrial Disputes Amendment Act, 1953, adding definitions of lay-off and retrenchment, and Chapter V-A.

anchor.surface_text: Textile Industry. From March 1, 1951, the Act was also, 76 6 made applicable to the Textile industry. In 1953 the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947 was amended by Industrial Disputes  Amendment  Act, 1953. The changes material to our purpose were the addition of two definitions and a new chapter in the Act.

facts.text: Industrial Disputes Act amended in 1956 by Industrial Disputes Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1956, inserting section 33C.

anchor.surface_text: In 1956 the Industrial Disputes Act was again amended by the Industrial Disputes  Amendment and Miscellaneous Provisions  Act, 1956. Section 23 of the Amending Act inserted section 33C which reads as follows 33-C. Recovery of money due from an employer.-

facts.text: Powers of Government under section 33C delegated to Second Labour Court, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The -powers of the Government under the above section admittedly have been delegated to the Second Labour Court Bombay. Section 31 of this Amending Act provides as follows Act number to override State laws.

holdings.text: The C.P. Berar Act contains no provision either for the recovery of money or for compensation for lay off
